title: How many total deaths attributed to COVID-19 in the US will be reported as of 1 May 2022?
preds: I believe that the deaths attributed to COVID-19 will be declining since almost everyone has their vaccines. But the virus will be affecting people throughout the years but the symptoms will be less.
Deaths are rapidly declining, and as of seven days before May 1st, we are only at 990K with a 7-day average of 376, thus I do not think the number will exceed 1,050,000.

I think it's between 975K and 1.05K because right now the cases are around 988K. Although omicron is now a big threat, there aren't many cases of death that I've heard or read about. Right now I'm seeing the graph, and it looks like it's stabilizing. So, I believe it'll stay between there to around 1M.

As of April 20th, 2022, the US CDC has reported around 987k deaths related to Covid-19, with a daily average of 385. May 1st is in 10 days from the day I'm writing this (April 21st, 2022). With an average of 385 deaths per day over the course of 10 days that is 3,850 deaths roughly, which does not clear past 1 million total deaths. There is the possibility of another surge of Covid related cases in the US between now and May 1st, as the average trend for cases is ever slowly rising (and death tolls follow, of course), but I find it unlikely to spark up furiously like it has in the past.
Total expected 993-994k (OWID) Perhaps 3k less via CDC
CDC reports 986,123 as of today. 7 day average is currently 488. Spike expected due to Spring break travel but wouldn't think deaths would increase significantly in the next 2 weeks.

April 1 total: 978,852 deaths
Days left to 1st of May: 30
Current rate: ~600 deaths / day, falling
Rate for >= 1,050,000 at 1st May: 2,371.6 / day (highly unlikely)

Repeating forecast from March 4th, I'm now 100% confident it will close within 5k of 1M
https://www.gjopen.com/comments/1409165
43 days left in the time period.  Current 7-day average 705 deaths/day.  Leaving current projection "as is" unless data significantly changes.

CDC reporting 973,515 as of today. 
Current 7 day moving average is 732. 
It's very possible that a new surge will happen as mask and vaccine requirements get lifted nationwide. The federal mask requirement is set to end on April 18. 
In places like NY, there are still 3.5 million without a booster shot but Covid vaccines show they can still protect most people from a serious cases causing death with 2 doses.  Surges in South Korea, Hong Kong, China are a warning for what may be yet to come in the US with a new wave,
Looking very likely to fall in the third bucket barring some sudden surge.
Going all in on Bin 3.  All my estimates come in around 1x10^6 to 1.05x10^6 total.
With 969,114 so far, and 41 days to go, my current forecast is almost exactly 1 million on May 1. The error bounds are shrinking every day and I'm ready to call this one.

Deaths will continue to fall for at least 20 days more. They may rise during the last at most 22 days of the forecast period. As long as they don't rise much faster than they fell, the deaths will stay in bin 3.
Adjusting very slightly here - I think there is some chance that a new surge results in more deaths.

Even with a dramatic downturn in deaths, it would take fewer than ~120 deaths per day to not hit 975k.  In order to exceed 1050000 it would require about 2000 deaths/day on average.  Such an uptick unlikely, since deaths lag behind cases, so even a surge in cases due to a new variant spreading would have a very, very short time to catch up.
43 days left and at current rates I project the total ending up between 1.01M and 1.02M.  Still leaving some chips in the next higher bin but expect bin 3 will be the final state.

Current US total deaths: 968k (as of 2022-Mar-18)
Days until 1 May 2022: 44
Rolling 7-Day daily average of new confirmed deaths: 1,197
(rolling 40-day projection is closer to 715)
(straight-line 51-day proejction is 810)
Estimated total deaths: 999K to 1.020M
https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html
https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#trends_dailydeaths

At 965k total currently and adding ~1,100 per day. To stay under 975 would require <200 cases per day on average, I predict a near 0% chance of this (perhaps the only way it could happen is if everyone died from something else in the next few days, but at that point, I'm not sure anyone would be here to give me points for it anyways...)
To stay under 1,050,000 the average needs to stay lower than 1,900, which we are well below today. Even with another spike it would be very difficult for the death rate to get this high to get that fast. For it to happen, it would require a wave to peak in the next 30 days and be more deadly than Omicron was and/or more contageous.

March 13 total: 965,336 deaths
Days left to 1st of May: 49
Current rate: ~1,200 deaths / day
Rate for <= 975,000 at 1st May: 197 / day (implausible)
Rate for >= 1,050,000 at 1st May: 1,728 / day (unlikely) At this point the 975,000 - 1,050,000 category seems by far the most likely, but the next category up is still just about possible (with a rapid BA.2 surge perhaps?)
Holding more or less steady. If we dip down a lot soon, I'll adjust down significantly.

52 days left from the March 10 CDC numbers.  The cumulative distribution of deaths is conforming to a nice logistic function. Still hedging that there is a small chance that shifts could occur in Bin 2 and 4, but have concentrated chips on Bin 3.

Current US total deaths: 963k (as of 2022-Mar-10)
Days until 1 May 2022: 51
Rolling 7-Day daily average of new confirmed deaths: 1,197
(rolling 10-day projection is closer to 1,240)
(straight-line 51-day proejction is 810)
Estimated total deaths: 1.004M to 1.028M
https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html
https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#trends_dailydeaths

959,533 as of March 10. 52 Days to go. 7 day avg is 1161 and declining. Dropping ~10%/week. So rough numbers if trend continues mean roughly 40-50k more cases by May 1, putting it at ~1M with a fairly high degree of confidence

All in. “The data made me do it.” 
Don’t want to jinx it, but we are rapidly running out of time for any scenario with a large new pulse of deaths to occur, e.g., from another new variant (too much time would be needed for it to emerge, spread to US, create a big wave of cases, etc.)

Average daily deaths are down significantly.  Extrapolating out that the bottom will be around 800 deaths/day in 56 remaining days, I get an estimated total of just over 1M totals by the deadline.  Upping bin 3 estimate accordingly.  Not quite ready to go to 100% but will probably pay for that in Brier Score points.
Daily deaths dropped sharply over the weekend, compared to previous weekends. Opening up the possibility of bucket two slightly.
I haven't been paying enough attention to this question.
Not seeing the sharp decline due to seasonality that I had expected.
Consolidating my bets on bin3, given there are 58 days left with a decreasing death rate

Current US total deaths: 953k (as of 2022-Mar-04)
Days until 1 May 2022: 58
Rolling 7-Day daily average of new confirmed deaths: 1,749
(rolling 40-day projection is closer to 1,500)
Estimated total deaths: 1.03M to 1.06M
https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html
https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#trends_dailydeaths

(https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&facet=none&uniformYAxis=0&pickerSort=asc&pickerMetric=location&Metric=Confirmed+deaths&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=false&Color+by+test+positivity=false&country=~USA) As of now we're at 954,518. In order to get above 1,050,000 by May 1st, we'd need to hit above 1646/day pretty regularly. I think that is decently unlikely, but not out of the question.
954,518 deaths as of 2 Mar, 1,554 deaths per day on a 7d rolling average, a bit spiky but dropping. 58 days to go. Need to average 1293 to exceed 1,050,000. Very very unlikely given the trendline.

I was aiming too low with this for a while, and now expect very close to 1M total. 
For me this places us safely towards the lower end of bin 3, with an implausible risk of an additional ~50k deaths.

Feb 26 total: 945,495 deaths
Days left to 1st of May: 63
Current rate: ~1,600 deaths / day
Linear extrapolation: 1,046,295 Cases and deaths both falling - though reduced test volume may bias the former and the latter is a little unsteady.  If the death rate stays around where it is, we might still pass 1,050,000 by the 1st of May, but that looks unlikely. Still enough time left on this question for a new variant to change things.

Current US total deaths: 950k (as of 2022-Feb-28)
Days until 1 May 2022: 67
Rolling 7-Day daily average of new confirmed deaths: 1,686
(rolling 40-day projection is closer to 1,430)
Estimated total deaths: 1.04M to 1.06M
https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html
https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#trends_dailydeaths

The trends are difficult to assess in the current situation, I would need to see what measures are announced stateside, notably as people will start socialising in the spring more.
https://www.worldometers.info/coronavirus/country/us/

My initial projection, only a week in, is way off. It seems that confirmed death numbers are holding reasonably steady. However assuming only a 1% day on day decline, this will still resolve in bin 3.

At 944k total currently and adding ~1,800 per day but clearly on the decline post-Omicron To stay under 975 the average would need to be <500 which would require a fast return to mid-summer lows.
To stay under 1,050,000 the average needs to stay lower than 1,766, which it is today and on the decline. Another variant would have to emerge and spread pretty quickly to impact the death rate before May 1 given the delay between case identification peaks and mortality peaks. Assigning most weight to 975k-1,050k range but leaving 20% open to a rapid slowdown and staying under 975k

At 939,645 deaths on 23 Feb with 67 days to go and the 7-day moving average of daily deaths moved up from 1582 to 1674. 
https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#trends_dailydeaths

Still consistently over 1,200, dipping down but looking historically we have not spent too much time below 1,200 daily. I'll grant that the pandemic could start to end by May, but I think that tapering-down is the only thing that will take us below 1,200, and I don't see it starting immediately, meaning that we'll actually need to get much lower, like 800 daily, in the final months. 941,889 deaths now. In order to get above 1,050,000, we need at least 1600 daily. Right now, that feels a little more plausible than dipping below 1,200, so I adjust accordingly.
Increasing the chances of bucket 3 due to a new Omicron variant being detected.
Trimming my bets and concentrating on bin 3.  The decreasing death rates, with the fall in cases, points towards the 975k to 1,050k range with a smaller chance of going higher.

Current US total deaths: 941k (as of 2022-Feb-23)
Days until 1 May 2022: 67
Rolling 7-Day daily average of new confirmed deaths: 1,884
(rolling 40-day projection is closer to 1,450)
Estimated total deaths: 1.03M to 1.09M

Total US deaths is at 932,894 as of this forecast. Daily deaths are currently at a 7 day rolling average of 1597, but dropping fast. During the trough of Oct 21-Dec 21, we barely got below 1k deaths per day. During the Summer 21 trough, it bottomed out around 300 deaths per day.
With around 70 days to go, chances are decent that there will be at least 70,000 more deaths as we experiences days with averages of 300-1500 per day. 
Source: https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#trends_dailydeaths
After another review I am accepting it is barely possible to get to 972k, as a best-case, and 978-995k looks more likely depending on how low cases get.

Some very rough maths. Deaths lag cases quite significantly. Deaths started to fall on a /day basis after the 10th Feb. On this day 211k was the rolling average of cases, but the peak happened in mid January. This is inline with the 2-4 week lag from cases to deaths we have seen throughout the pandemic. Between the 10th and today, deaths have gone from 2.5k to 1.8k (28% reduction). Cases took 11 days from the mid jan peak to drop 28% by the 26th. Cases have dropped a further 85% since then. If that is reflected in the deaths between now and 21st March (27 days taken for the 85% drop in cases), then we would expect to see around 270 deaths/day by then. If we naively assume the same rate of decay until May, we'd expect to see 25,000 more deaths. In order to get into bin 4, there needs to be roughly 39,000 more deaths. I think this is still quite possible since the decay in deaths almost certainly won't be as clear cut. However I'm thinking it's more likely to be under 975k.
Assessing that BA.2 will not significantly add excess deaths relative to the current trend. Only way to overshoot bin #3 now is the emergence of a brand new variant. Increasingly short time window.

Currently at 926k and adding ~2-3k per day which would put us over 1,060k by May, but Omicron cases are way down, and the death count is usually lagging by 2-3 weeks from that so I'm projecting the pace will slow dramatically. With ~70 days left, being under 975k would require the average to be <700 per day, which we saw last April to August and even briefly in Nov. That seems the most likely case now unless a new variant emerges in the next few weeks (again, as the death rate usually lags by a few weeks of the cases)

934,321 on 18 Feb, 72 days to go. 2,197 7d rolling average. Contrary to my last rationale, average daily deaths started declining on 10 Feb, 8 days earlier than I predicted. In fact, the peak daily death count had already happened when I made my forecast on 11 Feb. Opportunities for humility abound. To exceed:
* 975,000 deaths requires a daily average of 565. (Bin 3)
* 1,050,000 deaths requires a daily average of 1,606 (Bin 4)
* 1,125,000 deaths requires a daily average of 2,648 (Bin 5) I'm dropping Bin 5 from future estimates as we are already below that daily figure. I still find the crowd forecast over-optimistic about how fast and far death counts will drop; the US still has one of the least-vaccinated, least-healthy elderly populations in the developed world; they are doing pitifully little to vaccinate and boost nursing home residents. I'm not ready to revise my previous forecasts that  > "we will have a lot of daily deaths (>1,000 average daily until the end of March). Assuming that bears out and no new, deadlier variants emerge, April 2022 death counts should resemble 2021 (±800/d)." Though I think the crowd has picked the right bin with about the right level of confidence.

https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#trends_dailydeaths
I might be slightly optimistic with 970-975k, so I'll hedge with the crowd and see how the next two weeks progresses.
The lowest background rate of deaths will decide where this ends up. About 1000 would get us into bin4 around 400 would be bin 2.

May 1 mid estimate (30 days @ 2,000 deaths / day, 47 days @ 1,000 deaths / day): 1,023,571
May 1 optimistic estimate (20 days @ 2,000 deaths / day, 57 days @ 500 deaths / day): 985,071 Cases have come down and deaths are beginning to slow, but there's only so much time left on the question.
I think it could be fairly close between bins 2 and 3.
Making some adjustments.  Cases are definitely slowing down and deaths will follow.

Cases have plummeted in the last 2 weeks at roughly the same rate they accelerated into the peak of the omicron wave; deaths have plateaued since 28 Jan. I forecast average daily deaths will start declining around 18 Feb, and the rate of decline will approximate the rate of increase before the peak. All of which is to say, we will have a lot of daily deaths (>1,000 average daily until the end of March). Assuming that bears out and no new, deadlier variants emerge, April 2022 death counts should resemble 2021 (±800/d). As of 9 Feb, the US has recorded 912,255 Covid deaths. The current 7d average is 2,546. 80/1 days remain until 1 May. To exceed:
* 975,000 deaths requires a daily average of 775. (Bin 3)
* 1,050,000 deaths requires a daily average of 1,701 (Bin 4)
* 1,125,000 deaths requires a daily average of 2,626 (Bin 5)

Current US total deaths: 916K (as of 2022-Feb-11)
Days until 1 May 2022: 79
Rolling 7-Day daily average of new confirmed deaths: 2,463 (but expected to quickly drop to ~1,500)
Estimated total deaths: 1.06M to 1.09M
https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html

Still heading towards 960-985k, barring a new variant of dramatic changes in social behaviour coupled with easing mandates. 
In other words this is the current optimistic realistic scenario.
Revising thanks to comments by @paulm. I think he's right. I haven't been spending enough time on this question. Even if cases never fall below 100k/day, deaths won't likely surpass 975k.
With the case peak past, upping bet on bin 3.
Long right tail because of Cromwell's Rule: http://lawrencecrocker.blogspot.com/2015/09/nothing-is-certain-cromwells-rule.html

US deaths have been alarmingly straight-line during the omicron surge. (thanks, @ctsats) Current US total deaths: 909K (as of 2022-Feb-03)
Days until 1 May 2022: 81
Rolling 7-Day daily average of new confirmed deaths: 2,463
Estimated total deaths: 1.10M to 1.12M
https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html

Current US total deaths: 909K (as of 2022-Feb-03)
Days until 1 May 2022: 81
Rolling 7-Day daily average of new confirmed deaths: 2,463
Estimated total deaths: 1.10M to 1.12M
https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html

The US has passed the peak in deaths. The rise also included Delta deaths, but given that the decline in cases is slower than the rise, the decline in deaths will also be slower than the rise. The death data to the peak are noisy, but it looks extremely unlikely that we'll see fewer than 100k additional deaths before May 1. As we're currently at 902.6k, I don't see how bin 2 will be possible. Bin 3 looks most likely, but it's still not clear how much damage BA.2 will cause. And there's always a possibility of a new variant.

No change to forecast for now. 12 weeks to go, 902k to date and cases falling. All now depends on continuing decline in cases, reinfections, BA.2 rising and any unforeseen issues changing the context.
Total expected 965-995k

Adjusting based on figures reaching 900k. Currently averaging ~2,700 per day as the Omicron peak passes. But project it will decrease back to sub-500 levels with an average around 700 over the 90 days. It is possible another variant emerges before then so leaving higher numbers possible

Everything that goes up, needs to go down. Since omicron started to climb up around November, it increased total death rates from 235 per 100k  to 268 per 100k - this is approx. 108k deaths. We are supposed to be on the top of the peak of deaths at this moment or very close - so imagining a symmetric bell to simplify, we should add another 108k death to the accumulative 888 k. Death numbers will reduce but will never be 0. This takes us pretty tight on the 975k - 1050k bracket. I will bet on this bracket at the moment, if I see higher trends I will move upwards.
Interesting article in NYT on Feb 1, "U.S. Has Far Higher Covid Death Rate Than Other Wealthy Countries": https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/02/01/science/covid-deaths-united-states.html

Cases are obviously decreasing in the US and hospitalizations are slowing.  UK numbers have leveled off for reasons that aren't clear to me.  I'm moderating my forecast based on expectations that the acceleration will moderate as we see the familiar logistic curve of deaths form.  As a result I'm pushing my  bets downward towards Bin3 and 4.

Jan 31 total: 884,853 deaths
Days left to 1st of May: 90
Current rate: ~2,200 deaths / day
May 1 linear extrapolation (@ 2,200 deaths / day): 1,082,853 Cases are falling and I expect the death rate to drop over the next fews weeks.  However in the UK cases have so far levelled out at about half of the initial peak and I'm concerned the same may happen in the US.  Also numbers so far are in line with the second highest scenario from my previous comment (#4, 1,020,474 deaths).  So I'm shifting my forecast up a little.

Zeroing out deaths above 975,000 because of more confidence in lower death rate for Omicron, as well as seasonality. Also lowered "Fewer than 900k" after some simple forecasting. It looks like the total number of deaths will be right around 900k, and hard to tell how quickly the death rate will decrease from now (the end of winter) to May (spring).

Current US total deaths: 887K (as of 2022-Jan-31)
Days until 1 May 2022: 90
Rolling 7-Day daily average of new confirmed deaths: 2,376
Estimated total deaths: 1.09M to 1.11M
https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html update your forecast! total cumulative US deaths is already over 900K
Revising my distribution some based on most recent data.  There may be some upper tail risk if the death numbers accelerate.

879,971 as of Jan 28. 7 day deaths per 100k is at 4.78, which is higher than I'd expected but puts it more firmly in Bin 3 so I'll move the odds more in its favour. Since the total caseload is tapering off now It looks like the general forecast should move downward.
CFR continues gradual decline as case numbers start to head steadily lower after the peak. Hopefully this will get closer to the break at 975k.

Assuming the rate remains similar to the past three months, the next three months will see the total just above 1M in the US. Leaving some room for a) Omicron being less deadly and there not being another wave or b) Omicron turning out to be deadly but delayed or a new deadly variant having a wave before May.
I think it's a bimodal distribution, because the threat from a new variant cannot be excluded. If this wave has a wide peak then I think it lands in the 4th bucket.

50,000 over the last month and I think we'll likely see the same over the next month, currently at 864k. So Feb. 25 I'd expect it to be around 914k. I think cases are likely to continue declining, so my guess is March we'll see 25-40k deaths and April will add 15-35k deaths. That puts May 1 at a rough range of about 954 to 989k. I'm keeping my tails wider than that though since it's a rough guess and COVID is hard to predict.

The peak in deaths would have to fall off extraordinarily quickly starting in the next few weeks (no “plateauing”) in order that a bin #2 outcome could occur. I’m increasingly finding that to be less credible because of the high fraction of unvaccinated, and the fact that there is much more variability in the timing of how long patients are sick in hospitals before dying (compared to the low variability in when everyone got sick, which is remarkably fixed for Omicron).
(E.g., Figure 2, https://bmcinfectdis.biomedcentral.com/articles/10.1186/s12879-021-06371-6 ) Additionally, there is evidence that significant excess deaths associated with COVID will arise in the months after the serious cases of infection. How many of those are counted as  official “COVID deaths” is unclear. 
https://thehill.com/changing-america/well-being/longevity/583782-new-study-finds-serious-covid-19-infection-could-be?amp These factors—taken together with extrapolation of current death rates—strongly point to bin #3.

Baseline forecast appears headed just under 1M deaths (996,159). There is still uncertainty regarding the speed of decline and the timing of this wave's peak. The final tally will fall into bin 2 if we are near peak and the rate of decline is greater than 8% per week. Bin 4 occurs if this wave continues up for more than another two weeks or so before declining. Given the current data, it appears the wave is peaking now and bin 3 is the most likely outcome. The next couple of weeks should provide the data to hone in on the answer.

Two weeks since my last forecast. Since then it appears Omicron cases have peaked in the US but there's no sustained decline yet. Deaths are climbing but the paces is decelerating. However, the omicron wave is hitting the less-vaxed-and-boosted parts of the US, so even a drop in aggregate cases may not results in an equivalent decline in fatalities. As of 23 Jan the US has recorded 866,540 Covid deaths. The current 7d average is 2,188. 96/7 days remain until 1 May.  To exceed:
* 975,000 deaths requires a daily average of 1,118. (Bin 3)
* 1,050,000 deaths requires a daily average of 1,891 (Bin 4)
* 1,125,000 deaths requires a daily average of 2,665 (Bin 5)

current 868k and a 7 day average of 2300 and climbing. 
Would need less than 333/day between now and 1May to hit bin 1
bin 2: 333 to 1115
bin 3: 1115 to 1896
bin 4: 1896 to 2677
bin 5: 2677 to 3458
bin 6: 3458 to 4240
bin 7: Megadeth Cases peaked just over a week ago. from past discussions we have established that deaths delay infections by about 3 weeks so could expect further increases for another 2 weeks. If we expect it to go up for a bit longer as the vulnerable cant be saved it might hit 2700 to 3000 and then decay during Feb. might get back down to a lower level in March and April but the damage will be done.
Modelling an increase by 50/day for next 12 days up to 2900 (curently increasing faster than this) and then dropping by 50 per day until 1 April we would already have 980k so excluding bin 1 and 2 with a month to go.

Slight shift upwards again, which suggests the earlier lower range is becoming less likely
Expecting 1005-1055k

Similar to discussions by Campbell (https://www.youtube.com/user/Campbellteaching) and others regarding UK and SA numbers, the total deaths are lower with Omicron.  Am adjusting some based on this week's numbers.

Current US total deaths: 866K (as of 2022-Jan-22)
Days until 1 May 2022: 99
Rolling 7-Day average of new daily confirmed deaths: 1,974
Estimated total deaths: 1.03M to 1.09M
https://coronavirus.jhu.edu/map.html

If the average over the period is above 1200ish, we'll fall into the higher bucket. If it's below, we'll fall into the lower bucket. I feel pretty confident right now it's the higher one, but I'll track this.

Seeing several reports that case counts for the US appear to have peaked at a 7-day average of 806k on Jan 14. 
"Omicron grew from approximately 35k daily cases on Dec 14 to ~800k daily cases in ~4 weeks. 
Downturns are being observed in NY, NJ, MA, FL but many states are not yet at peak case loads. 
There are estimates that as of Jan 17 the US has a cumulative 15 million confirmed cases of Omicron, or approximately 4.5% of the population infected. 
The large majority, over 90% of these, accumulated since Dec 14. 
There may be a longer tail of circulation after the peak (as seen in South Africa), but a rough expectation would have an equivalent number of cases in the next 4 weeks on the other side of the peak. This would suggest 36-46% of the US infected by Omicron by mid-Feb. 
40% of the population infected by a single pathogen in the span of 8 weeks is remarkable and I can't think of an obvious modern precedent. Flu seasons generally have perhaps 10% infected in the span of 16 weeks." (Source Trevor Bedford, Fred Hutch) - 7 day average in the US is 1,974 deaths now (total deaths reported today 3,376) In New York City, where 83% of the population has at least one dose of a Covid vaccine, the Omicron wave increased Covid deaths significantly (1,604 deaths reported in past 14 days; 642 in the 14 days ending on Jan 7; and 188 deaths in the 14 days prior to Dec 16). Considering this, vaccination rates nationwide, and Omicron's infection rate, it's very likely we'll see over a million total deaths by May 1.

Adjusting forecast towards crowd, but still maintaining a higher chance of bin #2 because of expected sharp, large drop in new deaths in ~1 month from now. Bin #3 is the other vastly more likely outcome/scenario. Only emergence of a new variant or unforeseeable major systemic problem with the health care system could lead to higher bin outcomes, and these are very unlikely.

Dateline 1-18-2022. Increasing deaths likelihood because on day one of the newly installed governor of Virginia, he ordered people to die unnecessarily. I'm not exaggerating, because his ban of mask mandates in the state's public school system will have that effect, unless the lawsuits against his new rule soon overturn his order. Source: https://wtop.com/virginia/2022/01/confusion-lawsuit-follow-virginia-governors-order-on-masks/

Barring the emergence of some new variant that escapes a lot of existing immunity and/or is a lot more virulent, I think deaths could well end up in bin 2, although it could be somewhat close to the line with bin 3.
Minor update based on most recent numbers.
If you compare the ratio of deaths today with this day last year then multiply it with the number of deaths that occurred in this period last year the number just gets into 975-1050 range

Happy to move forecast back towards 995k +- 25k, after concerns the number could drift quite a lot higher. Checking current CFR and expected case number peak, then reducing CFR to allow for vaccination and Omicron’s less severe hospitalisation.

844,841 as of Jan 13. 3.65/100k death rate, up from 2.43 2 weeks earlier. Looks like still on an upward trend. Updating with simple Holt trending on log cumulative deaths.  I then aggregate with selected peers to account for the many things I may be missing in my own thinking and modeling.  Appreciate the reasoning of @paulm and @smingers as they extrapolate out what could occur. However, that said, the deaths appear to be occurring mostly in the unvaccinated with significant comorbid conditions (eg, DM, CHF, COPD, etc) so I expect the overall number to be limited.  Bin 3 is my current best choice for where this may end up.

Sadly, reports of death from Omicron are now strongly accelerating. A ~3 week+ lag seems to exist between onset of explosive growth in cases and onset of increased death rates. Now the big questions only seem to be how high will the average death rates spike to and how sustained will the peak be. Slightly adjusting forecast to add weight to higher bins. Lowest bins remain possible but the increase in deaths will need to taper off quickly to keep the ultimate tally lower in that scenario. https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2022/01/09/us/omicron-cities-cases-hospitals.html

If the death rate stays where it has been for the last 2 months, the number of deaths will fall in the 975k-1.05 mil range. Since those rates are largely driven by unvaccinated and vulnerable population segments, it will probably not change drastically for a little while.

My expected range has moved up slightly, with the mean closer to 1M. Any increase in deaths as a result of the Omicron wave rules out bin 1. I’ve allowed margin of 15% increase on expected peak rate of death for bin 4, and an option for unknowns such as a new variant, reinfections, Delta to remain at around 5% prevalence to slow the decline towards close. 
Vaccination rates have slowed and may not have time to change the CFR much before close. In terms of risk I think bin 3 is starting to look most likely.

832,118 as of 5 Jan, 1,191 deaths / day rolling average. 116 days until 1 May. Crudely assuming a steady rate results in 971,318 deaths by then. To exceed 1,050,000 would require a daily average of 1,878 over the remaining period.
To exceed 1,125,000 would require 2,740. We have never seen a sustained death rate that high for so long.

I looked at historical data presented by the CDC over 2021 to get an idea of the typical increase in COVID deaths by month. I did so working backwards by finding how many people died per month: 21-Dec	21-Nov	21-Oct	21-Sep	21-Aug	21-Jul	21-Jun	21-May	21-Apr	21-Mar	21-Feb	21-Jan
39501	32530	42882	53829	33308	9303	9229	15872	19955	31016	63312	94804 I then looked at how many people died from COVID from January to April in 2021 (209,087 deaths) and added this to the current total (825,106 as of 1/5). This yielded a total of 1,034,193. Because the variant of COVID appeared to be more severe at the beginning of last year, and vaccination rates were significantly lower, I used this as an upper bound for my estimate. I then focused on how Omicron was behaving, focusing on Oct through Dec (although Omicron was detected in November, I'm of the opinion it was likely around for the month prior to that). I found the average from the three months then projected it to occur over the next four months to get 153,217.33 deaths. Using this number as a lower estimate, the total number of deaths by May would be 978,323. I think even this number might be a little high, as we've already appeared to have peaked in COVID cases in many regions.  The way the pandemic has been behaving has been in peaks and valleys, and I think we will be heading to a low point over the next few months in case numbers. Furthermore, vaccination efforts have continued to increase as well as treatment methods. That's why I think it's most likely we end up between 900,000 and 975,000 by May 1, with a strong possibility it's below 900,000.

It looks like we are on track to hit about 1M at the current rate of about 1200 per day. But we will probably see an increase for awhile followed by a decrease.  The death rate from Omicron is a bit of an unknown, and the Omicron surge appears to burn out, making forecasting a challenge.

As of January 3rd, 2022 we have a 7-day average of ~1300 deaths per day with a 7-day case average of ~481,000. I believe that we are approaching the peak soon and we will see a sharp decline in the total. The total deaths as of January 3rd, 2022 are 826K. A consistent amount from January 3rd, 2022 to May 1st, 2022 gives us 117 days * 1300 deaths for an additional 152,100 deaths. This puts us at 826K + 152K = 978K. My COVID-19 estimation is a rapid rise and rapid fall. Omicron acting as a mandatory vaccine for a large portion of the population and preventing transfer of other variants for a while. Having such high case rates and low death rates relative, makes me very optimistic. I don't see a tremendous rise in deaths awaiting, but I do anticipate a big decline in deaths. Pfizer's treatment, milder cases, deaths not peaking, 2 vaccines + booster - should be more optimism. I'm having a hard time seeing 1 million + deaths as likely but I could be totally wrong about the trends. If we average <632 deaths we will remain under 900,000. The other period where we kept it under this level was about May 2021 - Aug 2021. I don't see this as THAT unlikely compared to the other forecasters.

As usual with long-term Covid questions, this question has many moving parts.
Current number: 824k. 
It's possible that Omicron could infect 1/3 of the US population and be 1/10 as lethal as Delta. 110M * ~0.0005 = 55k. 824k + 55k = 890k. This is possible. It could also be 50% as lethal as Delta: 110M * ~0.0025 = 275k. We really don't know what the case fatality rate is for Omicron yet, and we don't know what portion of the US will get it. It's also not inconceivable that hospitals could be so overwhelmed by a sharp Delta peak that people with Covid who in other circumstances would have lived will die from lack of treatment. There could also be a wave of another variant that sweeps through before May 1, much like Delta in India in April 2021, although hopefully paxlovid will help keep deaths down by then. Leaving the options open for now.
New to the party so I'm starting with a fairly broad distribution based off a simple logarithmic projection.  Will trim low probability bins as time goes on.

There were 166,000 over the last 4 months. That period included the peak of the first Delta wave [1]. We can already see that Omicron has a higher peak in cases, but there's good reason to believe Omicron will be less deadly [2]. Some of that may be due to intrinsic properties of the variant, some may be due to more people being vaccinated. I think the prevalence of Omicron balanced with its probable reduced lethality to me seems like a good guess at the next 4 months would be to assume the same number of deaths as the last four months. So I'm roughly centering around 816 + 166 = 982,000 deaths. But keeping the distribution wide because we still don't know a lot about Omicron and waves can vary substantially. I'm also skewing toward the lower side a bit because 166k deaths over 4 months would imply ~1400 deaths a day, and it's possible we could see Omicron peak quickly and supply immunity to the population that protects somewhat in the last two months or so of the question period. [1] https://ourworldindata.org/explorers/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=2020-03-01..latest&facet=none&pickerSort=asc&pickerMetric=location&Metric=Delta+variant+%28share%29&Interval=7-day+rolling+average&Relative+to+Population=true&Align+outbreaks=false&country=~USA [2] https://twitter.com/JamesWard73/status/1475946939426476049

Dec 22 total: 809,300 deaths
Days left to 1st of May: 130
Current rate: ~1,200 deaths / day In the short term I expect the death rate to go up, due to a widespread Omicron wave.  But we're beginning to see evidence its less lethal than previous waves, and it isn't clear if the gigantic spike in cases predicted in the UK (and rest of Europe) is turning out as bad as expected (perhaps due to changes in behaviour - will this be replicated in the US?).  Even if there *is* a big spike in the US it probably won't be sustained.  So I *think* the most likely outcome is a moderate spike in the death rate followed by a decrease in the longer term as the more dangerous Delta variant is squeezed out. There are a lot of unknowns though.  Especially in February and beyond, where we can't really say what the relative proportions of Delta / Omicron / potential other new variants is likely to look like. Starting (cautious) prediction:
 - 130 days of 600 - 1,200 deaths / day with a possible spike adding +50K.
 - result in the range 887,300 - 1,015,300

New vaccines will continue to not be effective against all strains similar to flu vaccines. Miss reporting on cause of death (say from causes similar to Covid like flu deaths) will keep numbers high. Also political pressures due to election year will be a factor.

Considering May 5th year to year:
From May 2019 to 2020 deaths increased by 75k
From May 2020 to 2021 deaths increased by 504k
From May 2021 to 2022 deaths increased by [933k] (assume an optimistic matching increase to least year of +429)
That would make the total 1521k in May. Considering Dec 24th year to year:
From Dec 2019 to 2020 deaths increased by 334k
From Dec 2020 to 2021 deaths increased by 482k
From Dec 2021 to 2022 deaths increased by [630k] (assume an optimistic matching increase to least year of +148)
That would make the total 1446k in December. It would be miraculous to "flatten" the year-to-year increase to 1400-1600k and that is 200k more than the minimum upper estimation bucket/discretization.
That being said, I have no idea what I'm doing so I'll smear 10% down toward less than 1275k

1,675 daily daily deaths is the current 7 day average; 3,287 deaths recorded yesterday. Assuming vaccination will continue to increase (many in the press are blaming failures to reach vaccination goals on "messaging" and specifically blaming it on the current president as the messenger. But disinformation, misinformation, fear have played the biggest role on lagging vaccination rates around the world. Notably, political affiliation continues to be the number one factor in vaccination rates in the US. Trump's clear and direct appeal to vaccinate (as of yesterday's interview in which he said "we're not seeing deaths in vaccinated people" and then confirming he had received a booster shot) we should expect to start seeing an effect just not clear how big if message is not amplified. Conservative news and media such as Fox --which almost triple viewership in the US when compared to liberal outlets-- continue to bombard airwaves with daily anti-vaccine, anti-mask messaging and content.
Omicron, even if milder than Delta, will run through  the population in the  following weeks and months and health care systems will get strained in many states. Going with 2,000 deaths daily average for now (assuming will be higher in January and February then start subsiding in March/April) but EU, global forecasts for next 6 months are not encouraging to overall picture. As for available treatments, the Pfizer and Merck pills to treat Covid at home won't be available til late January and they're talking about an initial production of 250,000 pills for Pfizer only. 2 monoclonal antibody treatments are already not being used un NYC hospitals for Omicron (source NBC News), only GlaxoSmithKlein's seems to work against Omicron and it's already running out. 
In NYC, where 80% has a least one dose and over 90% wear masks in public, we're seeing long lines for testing and urgent care clinics have waits longer than 7 hours. Vaccine appointments in many areas are now running into January. Holiday gatherings and travel will add to the mix. 
Our systems take too long to respond --staffing and quickly assembling response teams is an issue in many places-- and local govs don't seem to have learned the lessons of the last year. A responsive federal government makes a big difference but even that has limited effects when there are delays in action in public health matters.
If omicron is less deadly than I would like for a decrease in death rates. Will watch for signs of a rapid slowdown or rise in the next three weeks.
Initial forecast based on “eyeball” extrapolation to data. Higher bin outcomes correspond to unexpected scenarios where the Omicron wave somehow causes a large new wave of deaths.

Daily death rate 7-day average today in the US is 1,348. With the Pfizer pill and continued vaccination/boosting, I think that will decrease by 75% to about 337 in the next few months. For simplicity, I'll calculate that as current daily death rate continuing at 1,348 through February, then March 1 suddenly dropping to 337. Today is Dec 23, 2021
68 days till Mar 1
Est. deaths between now and Mar 1 = 68 * 1,348 = 91,664
# days between Mar 1 and May 1 = 61
Est. deaths between Mar 1 and May 1 = 61 * 337 = 20,557
Est. deaths between now and May 1 = 91,664 + 20,557 = 112,221
Total US covid deaths to date = 810,000
Est. total deaths by May 1 = 810,000 + 112,221 = 922,221
